\documentclass[oneside,english]{amsart}
\usepackage[T1]{fontenc}
\usepackage{geometry}
\geometry{verbose,tmargin=1in,bmargin=1in,lmargin=1in,rmargin=1in}
\usepackage{amsthm}

\makeatletter
%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%% Textclass specific LaTeX commands.
\numberwithin{equation}{section}
\numberwithin{figure}{section}

\makeatother

\usepackage{babel}
\begin{document}
\title{WCSAM 206 In-Class Midterm Review}
\author{Kenan Ince}
\maketitle
\begin{enumerate}
\item Encrypt the following, if it's possible for someone with a key to
decrypt it, or explain why it's not possible.
\begin{enumerate}
\item ``open the box'', shift cipher, $k=12$
\item ``open the box'', affine cipher, $m=12$, $k=1$
\item ``don't forget the key'', keyword cipher with keyword ``aubergine''
\item ``forget the key'', affine cipher with alphabet ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZ!?\$,
$m=25$, $k=1$
\end{enumerate}
\item Decrypt the following, if possible, or explain why it's not possible.
\begin{enumerate}
\item UJYJW UNUJW UNHPJI, shift cipher, unknown key
\item dcc ydp fufsp ydp, affine cipher, $m=7$, $k=3$
\item NBXBF BHBXBF, affine cipher, $m=12$, $k=5$
\item R2JJ NVI2, affine cipher with alphabet ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZ!?\$2,
$m=13$, $k=1$
\begin{enumerate}
\item To find $13^{-1}\mod30$, first do the Euclidean Algorithm on $30$
and $13$:
\begin{align*}
30 & =13(2)+4\\
13 & =4(3)+1
\end{align*}
\item Then solve for the remainders:
\begin{align*}
4 & =30-13(2)\\
1 & =13-4(3)
\end{align*}
\item Substitute the top equation into the bottom one:
\begin{align*}
1 & =13-4(3)\\
1 & =13-[30-13(2)](3)\\
 & =13-30(3)+13(6)\\
 & =13(7)+30(-3)
\end{align*}
\item Hence $13^{-1}=7\mod30$. Double-check:
\[
13\times7=91\equiv1\mod30.
\]
\end{enumerate}
\item YCYND YPYHMIKR YIRQ YINVWNOQ, monoalphabetic substitution cipher,
unknown alphabet
\end{enumerate}
\end{enumerate}

\end{document}
